title: Punishing proven perjurers after an execution
vignette: Two witnesses lie in court, an innocent defendant is executed, and only later is their perjury exposed.

options.text: Put the perjurers to death—one life for another.
Do NOT execute them; capital punishment for perjury applies only if the verdict was not yet carried out.

title: What penalty mirrors banishment?
vignette: Witnesses falsely testify that Taylor killed by accident—a crime that normally leads to banishment to a guarded community. What punishment should those witnesses receive?

options.text: Banish them as well—mirror what they tried to impose.
Give them corporal lashes, the standard penalty for perjury.

title: How many sets of liars get punished?
vignette: Three different pairs of witnesses repeat the same false story in court, and all are caught. Should every pair be punished?

options.text: Yes—each pair acted on its own and deserves the penalty.
No—penalise only the first pair; later pairs merely echoed them.

title: Perjury about privileged family status
vignette: Witnesses falsely claim that Dana was born into a special family class, blocking her from marrying anyone outside that class. What sanction best matches the harm they caused?

options.text: Corporal lashes—no direct way to mirror the status damage.
Bar the perjurers from receiving any benefits reserved for that family class.

title: Safe-zone murder by a family member
vignette: A victim’s relative sneaks into a protected city and kills the person who previously caused the victim’s death by accident.

options.text: Treat the relative as a murderer and sentence to death—the city was meant to be a sanctuary.
Excuse the relative—the right to vengeance never expires.

title: Killing when the accidental killer leaves the sanctuary
vignette: The person banished for accidental killing steps outside the city limits; the family member catches and kills him there.

options.text: No liability—the accidental killer lost protection by leaving.
Still liable for murder—taking a life remains a crime.

title: Runaway axe-head: accident or near-intentional?
vignette: A wood-worker swings an axe; the loose head flies off and kills a bystander. Was this close enough to intentional to warrant a death sentence, or does it count as a pure accident warranting banishment?

options.text: Treat it as near-intentional—capital liability.
Treat it as accidental—banishment only.

title: Paying money instead of banishment
vignette: An accidental killer offers the victim’s family financial compensation to avoid being sent away. Should this be allowed?

options.text: Yes—monetary settlement avoids the social cost of banishment.
No—loss of life cannot be traded for money.

title: Release of prisoners when the high official dies
vignette: By tradition, accidental killers are freed when the chief national official dies. Victims’ families start praying for his death so release comes sooner. Is the rule fair as-is?

options.text: Keep the rule—its symbolic atonement outweighs the odd incentive.
Change the system—either lengthen imprisonment or appoint lifetime officials to avoid that incentive.

title: Non-fatal revenge outside the sanctuary
vignette: The family member wounds, but doesn’t kill, the imprisoned accidental killer after catching him outside the protected city.

options.text: No liability—the same licence applies to non-fatal force.
Liable for damages—the licence extends only to killing.

title: One act, two prohibitions—how many lashings?
vignette: A single action breaks two separate religious bans at once. Should the offender receive one round of lashes or two?

options.text: One set—stacking pain is not allowed.
Two sets—each violation is punished separately.

title: Corporal punishment vs. financial fine
vignette: A thief’s crime legally triggers both corporal lashes and a double-payment fine. Which penalty takes priority?

options.text: Give the lashes and cancel the fine—no double punishment.
Skip the lashes and impose the monetary fine—victim compensation comes first.

title: When lashes might kill a frail offender
vignette: The standard number of lashes could kill an elderly offender. Should the punishment be carried out in full?

options.text: Yes—apply the full count even at serious risk.
No—reduce or cancel lashes to preserve life.

title: Are light violations worthy of heavy punishment?
vignette: A preacher says: “Even the smallest rule break deserves a beating.” Is this literal legal guidance or just moral hyperbole?

options.text: It’s rhetorical; actual penalties stay proportionate.
Take it literally; even minor sins merit strong deterrence.
